diff_hunk:
@@ -33,7 +33,7 @@
 
     <bean id="batchSqlSession" class="org.mybatis.spring.SqlSessionTemplate">
         <constructor-arg index="0" ref="sqlSessionFactory" />
-        <constructor-arg index="1" value="BATCH" />
+        <!--<constructor-arg index="1" value="BATCH" />-->
body: Have you pushed this by mistake or do you actually intend to disable batch mode?

I know this function wasn't used right now, but idea was that if you have an operation that inserts a lot of rfcs this call would be most efficient since it groups all the inserts to the same table together, that achieves 10x speed of single rfc insert called in a cycle. 
So I would still keep it for future refactorings.
Use get-process and output the exact number of processes, not just binary 0/100 output

diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,30 @@
+#!/bin/bash
+echo "setting up proxy for user Vagrant"
+grep "http_proxy" /home/vagrant/.bashrc
+if [ $? -eq 1 ]
+    then
+    sudo printf "export http_proxy=http://proxy.wal-mart.com:9080 \nexport https_proxy=http://proxy.wal-mart.com:9080 \n" >> /home/vagrant/.bashrc
body: I think we don't need to expose internal URLs here.

diff_hunk:
@@ -1265,9 +1266,13 @@ def ci_image_url(ci)
   end
 
   def ci_class_image_url(ci_class_name)
-    split = ci_class_name.split('.')
-    split = split[1..-1] if split.first == 'mgmt'
-    "#{asset_url_prefix}#{split[1..-1].join('.')}/#{split.last}.png"
+    if Cms::CiMd.look_up!(ci_class_name)
body: @lkhusid Isn't this a perf concern to call cms for each image URL construction? Earlier, it was just a string interpolation, now a network i/o involved here.
We don't need this check since we are passing `sshKeyPath`, which is null for local wo.

@abbas-sheikh-confiz reason fog-core was added to `common` was because `fog-azure-rm 0.3.5` has hard dependency on `1.43.0`. since the newer version of `fog-azure-rm` took out this dependency and depends on `~>1.43` we can take out `fog-core` from `common`. please remove it, validate and update the PR
1.0.4 is released to central. Could you update the version and test it?

had a discussion with @okornev on this. We do not need to handle replace as of yet. Because [1 replace == 1 workorder]. So it is kind of a zero sum. We will tackle a very rare scenario where "delete" part of replace code succeeds but "add" fails

diff_hunk:
@@ -26,6 +26,67 @@
 json_context      = ARGV[1]
 cookbook_path     = ARGV[2] || ''
 service_cookbooks = ARGV[3] || ''
+
+#
+# Check to see if we have older Ruby version
+# We are not modifying anything. Let's the Ruby
+# system kicks off this, if we detects older
+# version when can kick off the update process
+# only if it's hasn't been done.  If the update
+# has been performed then it will use the newer
+# Ruby instead of system Ruby.
+#
+if Gem::Version.new(RUBY_VERSION.dup) < Gem::Version.new("2.0.0")
+  valid_url_cmd = "curl --connect-timeout 10 -X HEAD #{ENV['RUBY2_BINARY_proxy']}"
+  install_ruby_cmd = "curl #{ENV['RUBY2_BINARY_proxy']} | tar Pxz  && /home/oneops/ruby/ruby-2.0.0-p648/bin/gem install bundler --no-ri --no-rdoc  && chown -R oneops:oneops /home/oneops/ruby"
body: Can't we detect the `ruby_binbary_path` depending on the version installed from `RUBY2_BINARY_proxy`? Hard cording to a specific minor version (`2.0.0-p648`) of ruby seems very fragile to me. Things can break if you change `RUBY2_BINARY_proxy` value in future.
